concept.title: External references in the relationship table
concept.shortdesc: Like other references in the ditamap, topic references in the relationship table can reference files external to the DITA collection, such as PDF files or Web URLs. The scope, format and type attributes in the topicref are used to specify the external reference.

conbody.p: A relationship table doesn't have to only refer to DITA topics within the current project. Like topicref elements used in the hierarchy section of the ditamap, topicref elements in the reltable can reference external files and URLs.

If you want an external reference target to open in a new window when output to a hypertext format, the approach is as follows.
Omit the type attribute in the relcolspec element (to apply the attribute to all topicref elements in the column) or the relcell element (to apply the attribute to all topicref elements in the cell).
Set the format attribute in the relcolspec or the relcell so that it describes the external file format (for example, if the external files are PDF files, set the format attribute to pdf).
Set the scope attribute in the relcolspec or relcell to external.

If you want the external reference target to open in the same window (when permitted by the browser and the external document type), the approach is as follows.
Set the scope attribute in the relcolspec or relcell to peer.
conbody.note: The type of output, and the publishing tool used, may affect the functionality of the scope attribute setting.

p.draft-comment: Peer and external just indicate whether resource is same directory structure (relative) or external directory structure (absolute). Peer will be displayed in same window (in hypertext outputs, and let's face it, this is really specific to hypertext outputs) and external in new window (target).
